title: Devil's Diary
descriptions:
Devil’s Diary (2007) is a supernatural teen horror-thriller that follows the discovery of a cursed notebook whose entries make dark desires come true—at a deadly cost. Set in and around a small-town high school, the story centers on two best friends whose lives are upended when they stumble upon a mysterious, leather-bound diary during a lunar eclipse. What begins as an outlet for anger and hurt quickly becomes a conduit for malevolent power, pitting friend against friend and igniting a chain of vengeful wishes that spiral into violence and tragedy.

It starts with Dominique and Ursula, socially outcast goth teenagers bonded by their outsider status and mutual contempt for the school’s popular crowd. One night, they sneak into a graveyard on a dare and, amid an uncanny celestial event, find a black diary inscribed with ominous markings. Intrigued, they open it to discover blank pages and cryptic rules that suggest anything written inside will come to pass. At first skeptical, they test it with a small, spiteful entry aimed at a cruel classmate who had humiliated them. When the wish comes true with eerie precision—resulting in an accident that injures the bully—the girls realize the book is not a prank. It is real, and it is powerful.

Emboldened, Dominique—who has endured relentless teasing—begins to write more, channeling pent-up rage into the diary’s pages. Ursula is uneasy with the escalation, sensing something wrong about how the entries exact their toll. The diary’s “fulfillments” are never simple; they twist circumstances in gruesome, unintended ways, leaving behind fear and guilt. Yet Dominique becomes intoxicated with the results. With every new entry, she gains confidence and social leverage. The book seems to respond to her growing appetite for retribution, feeding her with the illusion of control.

Word of the girls’ sudden good fortune and their enemies’ misfortunes spreads, sparking rumors that fuel tension at school and home. Dominique’s targets include the cheerleaders who torment her, a teacher who disregarded her complaints, and a smug jock who delights in cruelty. Each victim suffers a tailored downfall: broken bones from freak accidents, inexplicable fires, nasty public humiliations. Dominique justifies the harm as deserved payback. Ursula, troubled by the escalating body count and increasingly sinister coincidences surrounding the book, begs her best friend to stop.

The diary’s power exerts a subtler influence too. Dominique’s personality shifts—her bitterness curdles into remorselessness, and she becomes manipulative and obsessive about the book. The more she writes, the more the diary seems to own her. She grows distant from Ursula, who refuses to participate. The friendship frays as Dominique confides less and isolates more, guarding the diary like a treasure. She snaps at challenges to her authority and starts dressing and acting with the kind of aggressive confidence she once resented in her tormentors, alienating even the few people who care about her.

Ursula approaches a sympathetic priest and a librarian versed in occult lore, trying to understand what the diary is. Together, they piece together the notebook’s history: a recurring artifact linked to calamities and unexplained deaths across decades, referred to in scattered records as a “Devil’s Book.” The lore suggests that the book isn’t merely prophetic; it actively shapes outcomes, bending probability to orchestrate misfortune with a devilish penchant for irony. The priest warns that such a tool always exacts payment. In these accounts, the pattern is consistent: the user becomes isolated, consumed by the diary’s power, and ultimately destroyed by it.

Dom’s parents and teachers, noticing her dramatic changes, try to intervene but are outmaneuvered by coincidence and intimidation. The school sinks into a climate of fear, and Dominique revels in her newfound status, seeing herself as an avenging angel. Ursula confronts her, pleading that the book is evil, that the punishments have gone too far and hurt people who never laid hands on them. Dominique insists they’re reclaiming balance in a world stacked against them. The more Ursula resists, the more Dominique sees her as a threat to be controlled—possibly even an enemy.

When one of the diary’s more savage entries nearly kills an innocent student who tried to stand up for the girls, Ursula’s horror crystallizes into resolve. She decides the book must be taken from Dominique and destroyed. But that proves impossible. The diary is bizarrely resilient; attempts to burn it or tear it fail. Worse, it seems to defend itself. Those who try to interfere suffer accidents: falling bookshelves, electrical mishaps, sudden illnesses. The priest who offered guidance meets a tragic end under suspicious circumstances, and Ursula realizes the book responds with increasing ferocity as it feels threatened.
